Item 1. Business.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - Item 1. Business section in bullet points:

• Boeing operates in three reportable segments: Commercial Airplanes (BCA), Defense, Space & Security (BDS), and Global Services (BGS).
• The Commercial Airplanes segment develops, produces, and markets commercial jet aircraft to the commercial airline industry worldwide.
• The 737 narrow-body model and the 767, 777, and 787 wide-body models are part of Boeing's family of commercial jet aircraft in production.
• The Defense, Space & Security segment engages in research, development, production, and modification of military aircraft and systems, as well as strategic defense and intelligence systems.
• Global Services provides a full spectrum of products and services to commercial and defense customers worldwide, including supply chain management, engineering, and maintenance services.
• As of December 31, 2024, Boeing's total workforce was approximately 172,000, with 15% located outside the U.S.

Item 1A. Risk Factors.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART I - Item 1A. Risk Factors section in bullet points:

• The commercial aircraft market is predominantly driven by long-term trends in airline passenger and cargo traffic, with sustained economic growth and political stability being key factors underlying this growth.

• Demand for commercial aircraft is influenced by additional factors including airline profitability, availability of aircraft financing, trade policies, geopolitics, technological advances, price and other competitive factors, fuel prices, inflationary pressures, terrorism, pandemics, epidemics, sustainability-related preferences, environmental regulations, and reputational factors.

• The airline industry has historically been cyclical and very competitive, with significant profit swings and constant challenges to be more cost competitive.

• Significant deterioration in the global economic environment or the financial stability of one or more major customers could result in fewer new orders for aircraft or services, leading to lower revenues, profitability, and cash flows.

• The company's commercial aircraft backlog consists of aircraft scheduled for delivery over a period of several years, making it vulnerable to macroeconomic, industry, or customer impacts that could affect deliveries over a long period.

• Firm fixed-price aircraft sales contracts with indexed price escalation clauses subject the company to losses if cost overruns occur or if increases in costs exceed the applicable escalation rate.

• The company's revenue estimates are based on current expectations with respect to these escalation formulas, but actual escalation amounts are outside of their control and can significantly impact revenues and operating margins.

Item 1C. Cybersecurity.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - Item 1C. Cybersecurity section in bullet points:

• BA's cybersecurity strategy prioritizes detection, analysis, and response to known, anticipated, or unexpected threats.
• The company implements risk-based controls to protect its information, customers', suppliers', and third parties' data, systems, business operations, and products.
• BA adopts security-control principles based on the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Cybersecurity Framework, industry-recognized standards, and contractual requirements.
• The company leverages government partnerships, industry associations, third-party benchmarking, and regular internal and third-party audits to inform its cybersecurity processes.
• BA maintains physical, administrative, and technical safeguards, as well as plans and procedures for preventing and responding to cybersecurity threats or incidents.
• The company continuously monitors cybersecurity vulnerabilities and potential attack vectors, evaluating the operational and financial effects of any threat.

Item 5. Market for Registrant’s Common E.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II - Item 5. Market for Registrant’s Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities:

Item 7. Management’s Discussion and Anal.summary:
Here are the key facts from the Management's Discussion and Analysis section in bullet points:

• On January 5, 2024, an Alaska Airlines 737-9 flight made an emergency landing after a mid-exit door plug detached in flight.
• The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) grounded approximately 220 737-9 aircraft with a mid-exit door plug and required inspections to be performed on each of the grounded aircraft.
• On January 24, 2024, the FAA approved an enhanced maintenance and inspection process that was required to be performed on each of the grounded 737-9 aircraft.
• As a result of the accident, production rates were slowed and planned production rate increases were delayed to reduce traveled work in the factory and at suppliers.
• The Alaska Airlines accident significantly impacted BA's financial position, results of operations, and cash flows during 2024.
• On November 4, 2024, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers District 751 (IAM 751) voted to ratify a new contract, ending a work stoppage that paused production of certain aircraft models.
• The IAM 751 work stoppage significantly reduced aircraft deliveries in the second half of 2024.
• The new contract with IAM 751 and pay enhancements for certain non-union employees is adversely impacting BA's financial position, results of operations, and cash flows.

Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Di.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk section, formatted as bullet points:

• At December 31, 2024, a 10% increase or decrease in foreign currency exchange rates would have increased or decreased unrealized losses by $428 million.

• A 10% change in the fair value of investment funds for deferred compensation plans would increase or decrease the liability by $168 million.

• The deferred compensation liability was $1.7 billion as of December 31, 2024.

• At December 31, 2024, a 10% increase or decrease in commodity prices (market price) would have increased or decreased unrealized losses by $28 million.

• Commodity purchase contracts and derivatives are sensitive to changes in market price fluctuations.

Item 8. Financial Statements and Supplem.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART II - Item 8. Financial Statements and Supplementary Data section in bullet points:

• The Boeing Company's consolidated financial statements include the accounts of all majority-owned subsidiaries and variable interest entities that are required to be consolidated.
• The company operates in three reportable segments: Commercial Airplanes (BCA), Defense, Space & Security (BDS), and Global Services (BGS).
• The company has added a new financial statement line item to the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows for cash invested in Supplier notes receivable.
• The preparation of financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
• The operating cycle is generally longer than one year, with certain current assets and liabilities classified based on the duration of related contracts or programs.
• Revenue for commercial aircraft contracts is recognized at the point in time when the aircraft is completed and accepted by the customer.
• Payments for commercial aircraft sales are received in accordance with a payment schedule, with advances and progress billings considered normal and customary.

Item 9A. Controls and Procedures.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 9A. Controls and Procedures section, formatted as bullet points:

• As of December 31, 2024, the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer concluded that BA's disclosure controls and procedures were effective.
• The management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
• The internal control over financial reporting was evaluated based on the framework in Internal Control – Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
• The internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2024.
• Deloitte & Touche LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, audited and reported on the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting in Item 8 of this report.

Item 10. Directors, Executive Officers a.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART III - Item 10. Directors, Executive Officers and Corporate Governance in bullet points:

• As of February 3, 2025, the ages of Boeing's executive officers are not specified.
• The company has adopted a Code of Ethical Business Conduct for Directors and the Boeing Code of Conduct that applies to all employees (together, the Codes of Conduct).
• The Codes of Conduct are posted on the company's website at www.boeing.com/company/general-info/corporate-governance.page.
• No family relationships exist among any of the executive officers, directors, or director nominees.
• Disclosure regarding amendments to, or waivers of, the Codes of Conduct will be included in the 2025 Proxy Statement, which is expected to be filed with the SEC no later than 120 days after December 31, 2024.
